Description: Easy to construct mask using a handkerchief and hair ties, with an optional filter addition.
Audience: Risk: "Community: low risk, preventative measure, used for < 6hrs",Essential/Service workers: high risk for social exposure/community transmission
MedTeam Design Specific Notes:
- Note: This design is for use by members of the general public only and is not suitable for healthcare workers. 100% cotton is recommended for this mask, as cotton blends will be difficult to breathe through when layered. 
- Hair ties may contain latex or cause irritation to the ears. We recommend using other alternatives.
Other Notes:: Link 2 is a CDC resource page with instructional video at the bottom
Google Doc Notes:
Note: This design is for use by members of the general public only and is not suitable for healthcare workers. 100% cotton is recommended for this mask, as cotton blends will be difficult to breathe through when layered. 
Hair ties may contain latex or cause irritation to the ears. We recommend using some of the other alternatives listed at the end of the page.
Google Doc Note #2:
The US Surgeon General has also created a video demonstrating  this style of mask. (Visit this CDC resource page and scroll down to the embedded video.)

https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/cloth-face-cover.html

Coffee filters can be incorporated into this style of mask for additional filtration, as demonstrated in this CDC resource

https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/diy-cloth-face-coverings.html

Description: You only need an old t-shirt, scissors, our template linked (optional), and a pipe cleaner (optional) to make this mask. There is no sewing required.
Audience: Risk: "Community: low risk, preventative measure, used for < 6hrs",Essential/Service workers: high risk for social exposure/community transmission
MedTeam Design Specific Notes:
- Note: This design is for use by members of the general public only and is not suitable for healthcare workers. 100% cotton is recommended for this mask, as cotton blends will be difficult to breathe through when double-layered. 
- This variation has the advantage of creating a pocket that can hold additional filtration material.
Other Notes:: The imgur links are for the template used in the video and a helpful infographic.
Google Doc Notes: Note: This design is for use by members of the general public only and is not suitable for healthcare workers. 100% cotton is recommended for this mask, as cotton blends will be difficult to breathe through when double-layered.
Google Doc Note #2: This variation has the advantage of creating a pocket that can hold additional filtration material.

Description:
HK Mask is a reusable cloth mask with a disposable middle layer filter. It was invented by Dr. K. Kwong during the outbreak of COVID-19 in early 2020.

The design of HK Mask is referred by that of 3-layer surgical mask in the market. The HK Mask is composited with a disposable middle layer filter which is sandwiched by a cloth mask as the outer and inner layers. There are a number of material chosen for the middle layer filter ranging from Kitchen Towel Paper to Nanofilter.

The filtration efficiency of a piece of kitchen towel paper is close to that of N70. The mask can be safely used after replacing a new middle layer filter to a cleaning and sterilizing the inner and outer layer cloth
Creator: Dr. K Kwong
Audience: Risk: "Community: low risk, preventative measure, used for < 6hrs",Essential/Service workers: high risk for social exposure/community transmission,Healthcare: high risk of exposure to COVID patients
MedTeam Design Specific Notes:
'- Using different colors on the front (outside facing; lighter color is better) and back (inside facing) part of the mask is ideal so that the sides can easily be recognized
- If using to protect existing PPE, using a light color for the outside of the mask is best so that the wearer can easily see soiling
- This design does not incorporate pleats, which may allow for more rapid production. The addition of a filter is optional, as well as wire nose bridge support. This design may be useful as a protective cover for the dome-shaped N95 mask. OSMS recommends using non-latex elastic or more preferably fabric ties if donating to healthcare workers. The DXF files can be used to make a manual fabric cutting template or one for laser cutting fabric.
-
Other Notes:: So I added links to the HK mask patterns and DXF template files. Those were the only reason I added this mask to our doc because the resources were so good and I think they MUST be included somehow. All of the design links from the Google Docs are relevant.
Google Doc Notes: Note: This design does not incorporate pleats, which may allow for more rapid production. The addition of a filter is optional, as well as wire nose bridge support. This design may be useful as a protective cover for the dome-shaped N95 mask. OSMS recommends using non-latex elastic or more preferably fabric ties if donating to healthcare workers. The DXF files can be used to make a manual fabric cutting template or one for laser cutting fabric.

Description: The MakerMask:Surge is designed to wear as a standalone mask for droplet protection and filtration. The Surge design provides a water-resistant alternative to cotton masks, optimized for ease of construction by home sewists.
Creator: Jocelyn Songer and Alexander Bissel
MedTeam Design Specific Notes: '- Note: “Non woven polypropylene (NWPP) is commonly used in surgical masks and can be easily sewn into masks that can block the spread of droplets from coughs and sneezes” - Community Pleated Masks.
Other Notes::
Cautionary statement: There is substantial variability in the composition and coatings of NWPP. Follow guidance to ensure accurate identification of materials. NWPP can be boiled to sanitize/decontaminate it. For more information, please view this thoroughly researched information page at Maker Mask. 

https://makermask.org/the-big-four-criteria-for-community-mask-
materials/
Google Doc Notes:
Note: “Non woven polypropylene (NWPP) is commonly used in surgical masks and can be easily sewn into masks that can block the spread of droplets from coughs and sneezes” - Community Pleated Masks. 

Design uses ties behind the head rather than elastics, which is preferred practice.
Google Doc Note #2: Cautionary statement: There is substantial variability in the composition and coatings of NWPP. Follow guidance to ensure accurate identification of materials. NWPP can be boiled to sanitize/decontaminate it. For more information, please view thoroughly researched information page at Maker Mask.  https://makermask.org/the-big-four-criteria-for-community-mask-materials/

Description: This pattern is a pleated rectangular “surgical-style” face mask that is easy and quick for new sewists and combines the best elements of well-known patterns such as the Deaconess, A.B. mask (For a nurse, by a nurse), We Can Sew It, the Cynthia, and the Erin.
Google Doc Notes: Note: This resource also includes variations on how to incorporate elastic (recommended for personal use only/not for donation). This resource also matches users with donation sites to facilitate distribution of maker-produced masks.

Note: This design does not incorporate pleats, which may allow for more rapid production. This may result in bulkier side seams that cause the mask not to sit as flush against the face. Ties are preferred over elastics, especially if donating to healthcare workers.
